review_title: Call yourselves a charitable organisation!!!!! Lies from Day 1
pros: None! There minimum of 5 words
cons: Worked in HO at Leeds for some weeks, stuck in a grotty little office for some weeks with the minions licking up, also the "blue eyed girls", who grassed on you if you opened your mouth!!! It was like being back in a nursery with all the 20 somethings thinking they knew all about life. No help or support whatsoever. If you didn't attend their voluntary support meetings like the LGBT community you were frowned upon, not that I am homophobic, but I'm afraid it puts these people in a bad light, trying to shove their beliefs down your throat, when really you just want to get your work done. Ha yes, speaking of which, I was lied to from Day 1, my job did not match the description to which I applied for, so shame on you, your loss. Some people were nice, but the majority were nasty and rude.

pros: Nothing at all with this company
cons: Second rate company, I worked for this company for only a relatively short period of time thank god! During my time there I reliased that support from upper management was non existent I soon found myself in a position where I had valid concerns over the seniors conduct towards me. Upper management missed this off as jovial banter!!! I had various hideous experiences while working for this company one been the senior referring me as I candy and a tease I also felt the senior missed no opportunity to stare at me in a lecherous manner. This vile individual was certainly the motivation I needed to move on, I’m staying postive and loving my current job within the care sector. I would strongly advice anyone to avoid st Anne’s .

job_title: Recruitment and Retention Assistant in Leeds, England
pros:
I recently worked at St Anne’s head office in Leeds in a temporary position; it was a perfect opportunity for me to re-enter an office environment ahead of a new career. 

I was immediately made to feel welcome by not only my own team, but by staff across the organisation as a whole. St Anne’s provide fantastic opportunities for you to network with members of staff across all worksites and areas of the organisation, especially through their various groups, such as Equality & Diversity and Fresh which are both brilliantly run. 

For a large organisation spanning Yorkshire and the North East, it feels as though everybody is working as one team at St Anne’s and I was able to build strong, positive working relationships with staff in the services working on the front-line with our clients. St Anne’s pride themselves on their core values, namely being person centred, and this really shines through across the organisation. 

My personal experience within the recruitment team gave me opportunity to work on a variety of projects and progressively learn more about the recruitment process and beyond.  I was supported closely by my manager and team to ensure I achieved my potential in the role and was able to go beyond this in order to challenge myself and learn more about the organisation, such as spending patterns and the interview process. 

Flexible working hours presented me with a fantastic work/life balance and I felt valued and motivated during my time at St Anne’s; I wholly recommend them as an equal opportunities employer.
cons: In terms of being in line with the regional average, the salary for a recruitment assistant is too low. Pay should reflect the importance of adhering to data protection on a constant basis and the diligence required within the role to ensure the right people are recruited to the organisation.

pros: Massively satisfying job, making huge differences to the lives of people who need support to live independently in the community.
cons: We are currently under going a consultation process which will pretty much devastate our terms and conditions, especially around sick pay. Not their fault, blame the government and their unwarranted attacks on the disabled, but it still leaves us in a race to the bottom.
